Texto: 
physical exam: non-contributory


ct scan to assess for worsening headache and visual problems followed by mri (see images).
unknown for this patient.  treatment options may include:
• medical - anticoagulation (heparin, coumadin), hydration, hemodilution
• interventional radiology - endovascular thrombolysis, stenting
• surgery - evacuate hematoma, etc.
non-contrast ct (nct): high attenuation (density) consistent with a blood clot in right transverse sinus, sigmoid sinus, and extending to a thrombosis of the internal jugular vein .

magnetic resonance imaging (mri): high signal intensity lesion (clot) in same structures seen on t1w.
note the distention of the involved venous sinuses by the thrombus.
dural sinus thrombosis, transverse and sigmoid sinus
• venous dural sinus thrombosis
• dural sinus thrombophlebitis
• venus sinus occlusion 8~)
this 24 year old woman had streptococcal pharyngitis 2 weeks prior to admission.  one week prior to admission, she had a lumbar puncture (lp) to evaluate for possible meningitis.  three days ago had a blood patch  for treatment of her persistent spinal headache (after the tap).
» companion cases: http://rad.usuhs.edu/medpix/medpix.html?mode=image_finder&srchstr=dural%20sinus%20thrombosis#top

• nejm review article - http://dura.stanford.edu/articles/stam_nejm05.pdf
• blind spots on imaing - http://radiographics.rsna.org/content/29/7/1877.full
• http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1162804-overview
• acute treatment of sinus thrombosis - http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2fs11940-008-0014-0?li=true
• http://stroke.about.com/od/causesofstroke/a/sinusthrombosis.htm
